caption: Table 1: Families of OD methods with the limitations they address.
description: This table categorizes outlier detection (OD) methods into families based on their approach and the limitations they address.  Classical methods are marked as addressing none of the limitations. Subspace methods aim to overcome the curse of dimensionality. Generative methods employing uniform distributions or parametric distributions struggle with high dimensionality and multiple views. Generative methods that model subspace behavior only partially overcome the limitations.  Finally, the paper's proposed method, GSAAL, is highlighted as addressing all three challenges.

caption: Table 1: Families of OD methods with the limitations they address.
description: This table categorizes outlier detection (OD) methods into families based on the limitations they address: Inlier Assumption (IA), Curse of Dimensionality (CD), and Multiple Views (MV).  It shows which limitations each family of methods successfully tackles (indicated by a checkmark) and which limitations remain unaddressed (indicated by an 'X'). The table includes classical methods, subspace methods, and generative methods with different distributional assumptions (uniform, parametric, and subspace-specific).  Finally, it highlights the Generative Adversarial Active Learning (GAAL) approach and the proposed GSAAL method, demonstrating that GSAAL is uniquely designed to overcome all three limitations.

caption: Table 1: Families of OD methods with the limitations they address.
description: This table compares several outlier detection methods based on three limitations: Inlier Assumption (IA), Curse of Dimensionality (CD), and Multiple Views (MV). It shows which limitations each family of methods addresses and highlights the proposed GSAAL method's ability to address all three.

caption: Table 1: Families of OD methods with the limitations they address.
description: This table categorizes outlier detection (OD) methods into families based on their approach (classical, subspace, generative) and the limitations they address (Inlier Assumption (IA), Curse of Dimensionality (CD), Multiple Views (MV)).  A checkmark (✓) indicates that a family of methods successfully addresses the limitation, while an X indicates that they do not.  The table highlights the novelty of the proposed GSAAL method, which is the only one addressing all three limitations simultaneously.

caption: Table 2: Real-world datasets and Competitors
description: This table presents the real-world datasets used in the paper's experiments, categorized by type and including dataset name and category.  It also lists the competitor outlier detection methods used for comparison, categorized by their approach (classical, subspace, generative).

caption: Table 1: Families of OD methods with the limitations they address.
description: This table categorizes outlier detection (OD) methods into families based on their approach (classical, subspace, generative) and the limitations they address (Inlier Assumption (IA), Curse of Dimensionality (CD), Multiple Views (MV)).  A checkmark (✓) indicates that the method addresses the limitation, while an 'X' indicates that it does not.  The table highlights the unique capabilities of GSAAL (Generative Subspace Adversarial Active Learning), the proposed method, in addressing all three limitations.

caption: Table 1: Families of OD methods with the limitations they address.
description: The table categorizes outlier detection (OD) methods into families based on the limitations they address: Inlier assumption (IA), Curse of dimensionality (CD), and Multiple Views (MV).  Each family is marked with a checkmark (✓) if it addresses a limitation and an 'X' otherwise. The table shows that classical methods fail to address any limitations, while subspace methods only address CD. Generative methods with uniform and parametric distributions address IA, but not MV. Generative methods considering subspace behavior address CD and MV but not IA. Finally, the proposed method GSAAL is highlighted as the only one addressing all three limitations.

caption: Table 1: Families of OD methods with the limitations they address.
description: This table categorizes outlier detection (OD) methods into four families based on their approach (classical, subspace, generative with uniform/parametric distribution, generative with subspace behavior) and whether they address three common limitations: inlier assumption (IA), curse of dimensionality (CD), and multiple views (MV).  A checkmark (✓) indicates that the family of methods addresses the limitation, while an 'X' indicates that it does not. The table helps to highlight the unique contribution of GSAAL, the method proposed in the paper, as it is the only method shown to address all three limitations.
